docs.abstract: The Obama Administration on Friday backed away from what would have been the first government-run insurance program for long-term care.
docs.snippet: The Obama Administration on Friday backed away from what would have been the first government-run insurance program for long-term care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama Administration on Friday announced that it was scrapping the Class Act, the government-run insurance program for long-term care authorized by the Affordable Care Act, essentially because the numbers could not be made to work. Robert Pear reports:
docs.abstract: The Obama Administration on Friday backed away from what would have been the first government-run insurance program for long-term care.
docs.snippet: The Obama Administration on Friday backed away from what would have been the first government-run insurance program for long-term care.

headline.main: Should Insurers Pay for Eating Disorders?

docs.abstract: As insurers are pushed to pay for residential treatment for eating disorders, the principle of equal coverage for mental and physical health is tested.
docs.snippet: As insurers are pushed to pay for residential treatment for eating disorders, the principle of equal coverage for mental and physical health is tested.

docs.abstract: A good deal of services that count toward gross domestic product involve getting Americans and companies into compliance with rules and regulations that promote inefficiency, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: A good deal of services that count toward gross domestic product involve getting Americans and companies into compliance with rules and regulations that promote inefficiency, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

docs.lead_paragraph: When pharmacies begin receiving lower dispensing fees for prescriptions under Medicaid, some stores may have to lay off workers, cut services or both.

headline.main: Lower Medicaid Dispensing Fees May Pressure Pharmacies
headline.print_headline: Lower Medicaid Dispensing Fees May Pressure Pharmacies

docs.snippet: When pharmacies begin receiving lower dispensing fees for prescriptions under Medicaid, some stores may have to lay off workers, cut services or both.

docs.lead_paragraph: People with eating disorders like anorexia are fighting insurers to pay for stays in residential treatment centers, an issue that is being considered by an appeals court in California.

headline.seo: Ruling Offers Hope to Eating Disorder Sufferers
headline.main: Eating Disorders a New Front in Insurance Fight
headline.print_headline: Eating Disorders a New Front in Insurance Fight

docs.abstract: Both sides are closely watching consequences of US Court of Appeals for Ninth Circuit decision, which ruled that insurers in California must pay for residential treatment for eating disorders and other mental illnesses under state's mental parity law; laws, also enacted in other states, generally require that coverage for mental disorders be equivalent to that for physical ailments, but parity can be difficult to define; Blue Shield of California, defendant in lawsuit, is seeking to have case reheard
docs.snippet: People with eating disorders like anorexia are fighting insurers to pay for stays in residential treatment centers, an issue that is being considered by an appeals court in California.

docs.lead_paragraph: If Medicaid’s equal access provision goes unenforced, providers will not participate.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by former Medicare and Medicaid administrator Bruce C Vladeck and Prof Stephen I Vladeck contends that, even as it defends constitutionality of new health care law's individual mandate, Obama administration may be complicit in eviscerating Medicaid by its participation in California suit that seeks cuts in its program; warns of danger of setting back broader goal of ensuring that all Americans have access to quality health care.
docs.snippet: If Medicaid’s equal access provision goes unenforced, providers will not participate.

byline.original: By BRUCE C. VLADECK and STEPHEN I. VLADECK

docs.lead_paragraph: 8:22 p.m. | Updated House Republicans have had a laserlike focus on dismantling various forms of federal regulations this month, the centerpiece of their job creation agenda.

headline.main: House Passes Another Bill to Reduce Access to Abortions

docs.abstract: The bill would prohibit using federal funds made available through the new health care law to buy health insurance policies that offer abortions.
docs.snippet: The bill would prohibit using federal funds made available through the new health care law to buy health insurance policies that offer abortions.
